reviewText:
Wow!
I must say that i have never expected to enjoy a Space Invaders clone as much as this.
So, starting the game, you are confronted with a settings menu that contains everything you need and some excellent music (soundtrack is included when you buy the main game) prematurely filling you with adrenaline that you will need later on. Then there's the selection between gamemodes being:Level Mode: Play through 30 different levels with a slight level of passive experience-based progression between levels. (data is autosaved)
Endless Mode: Mow your way through a procedurally generated neverending (hence the name) stream of enemies in the hopes of beating your high score.
Wave Mode: The same as Endless Mode, but in a rotation of waves (duh) that are all manually designed.Jumping into it i admit that i saw nothing but a weak space ship in a take on the classic coin-eating Space Invaders, but it didn't differ from the original enough to keep me interested. That was until it started borrowing some of Galaga's complexity, and classic shmup elements and pacing from the bullet hells such as CRIMZON CLOVER. And that is basically what this is, classic arcade Space Invaders/Galaga with shmup elements thrown into it.
But somehow, Void Invaders succeeds in not feeling like another one of these unoriginal ripoffs as instead of blending different existing games together, it does that and adds more to it. They added a lot of new enemies and bosses with original patterns and also new shmup-like temporary upgrade pick ups with not only more bullets in a wider range"
date: but besides that also a handful of unique upgrades that cause different playstyles and pacing
recommended: much like Bit Blaster XL.\nWhat also differs Void Invaders from other Space Invaders clones is that the general amount of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• happening on the screen is not inserted merely for the sake of eyerape. It actually adds to the aesthetic of the game. The way the particles are thrown on the screen is what many refer to as "artistically cohesive" in the sense that all of the explosion effects
hoursPlayed: the background and the unique screen tilt while moving actually fit together quite nicely. I'd say Void Invaders should switch places in reputation with Bit Blaster XL.\n\nDon't see stuff that should be here or vice versa? I'm open to constructive criticism."

reviewText:
Follow my curation : http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9273374-exorio

It's space invaders with a twist. And it's actually good. Simplistic gameplay, tight controls, and better yet : Endless Mode!

I'm fine with the overkill aesthetic, specially the explosions and flashes.

Although a little bit too overkill and make it hard to keep up on what happens on screen.

For the devs : Pls add an option to turn off the tilting screen, also it doesn't scale up to fill my whole screen. Oh yeah a controller support would be nice. At least XBox360 controllers.

Other than that, it's good, fun, enjoyable and strangely... somewhat relaxing.

Worth the asking price.

Update 08/22/2015

Dev added controller support, options for screen scaling and option to turn on/off wobble effect! Great job, dev! Game is much better now, highly recommended!

reviewText:
First of all, I was asked to test this game before the release by the developers.
When I played it the first time, it had a few bugs and I criticized some features of the pre-release game.
But within one or two days, the devs said to me that they improved (almost) all of the criticisms I had on the game.
This game might look simplistic, and while the gameplay is in a special way, the developers put a lot of time, effort and love in the development of this game.

The game is based on the old classic space invaders game, but this game offers much more. It offers amazing, colorful and flashing graphics, it has cool powerups for your ship, it offers the possibility for your ship to level up so it becomes stronger.
This game offers two modes: Endless mode and a mode where you have to complete levels, to move to the next level. In endless mode you can sit back, relax and enjoy while playing the game without a lot of pressure.
In the mode where you'll have to complete levels, you are trying over and over, finding the best way to complete the level and the tactic to beat the boss.

Overall, certainly worth the low price of 3 ‚Ç¨.

reviewText: A shooter that pays homage to classics like Space Invaders and Galaga. You collect power-ups, get XP to level up your ship (increased health, fire rate, etc.) and fight waves of enemies that move in different patterns. My only gripe so far is that there's no controller support; I really feel like a game like this would play better with a controller rather than a keyboard. And in case you can't tell from the screenshots, there are lots of flashing colors and lights in this game, so avoid this game if you can't handle such light shows.

reviewText:
There are not enough accolades that I could ever try to give this game.

Look...I know you'll hear a lot of people calling this a mix between space invaders and galaga...and,I suppose I can see it,galaga wise, with the well evolved  power up system...but,to me...and I don't think there are any space invaders influence discrepancies...and bonus on them for using my favorite space invader as their Mario....but I see,hear,and feel centipede as  the rightful mate of space invaders in all of this.

Let me just say that my love for this game  is based upon the endless mode.
The wave mode is wonderful...but simply not as gripping...although the boss battles are epic.

While you may not dedicate your life to this game,
it will turn you out every time that you come calling.
It will leave you breathless...
and you will feel your heart begin to beat again as the alien mushroom clouds and explosions subside...
and you see your own mushroom cloud...
the air returns to your lungs...

This game is intense.

9.11.15.


Ok.so I have dedicated more time to the wave mode.

I now find it equal to endless.

You would miss out quite a few interesting characters
by not embracing  it.




To the Devs:

All of the bright explosions...especially when the screen is full and the aliens are dying like flies in a fire...

is like Jedi mode for me...relaxing amidst a sea of chaos.
Just feeling where I am.

And...the screen shift...
I never really noticed it until I saw someone mention it in a review.

Thank you for your obvious aches and pains of love that delivered  this work of art.

I look forward to more from you.

reviewText:
Okay, I may only have played 40 minutes so far, but for some games that's all you need. I got to level 20 and...what a blast (excuse the pun!).
I have two words - Jeff Minter.
Am I right? Was Jeff involved with this game in some way, shape or form? It has the hallmarks of his style and is reminiscent of Llamatron and even his early Grid Runner on the Vic-20!
The game also has inspiration from Moon Cresta, Galaga and Phoenix too, as far as I can tell. It's brilliant! I bought it on sale but it's well worth the full asking price too.

Great fun!

reviewText:
I don't usually review games, but this one is the game that gets me back to reviewing after a while.

Void Invaders can be described as Galaga meets Monstercat. May be simple, but after a few levels, it gets you addicted to the game. At the same time, it gets harder really fast, too. I couldn't get past the second boss. Anyway, the game's soundtrack is really catchy and, best of all, it's free of charge. The price is low, and it is really worth playing, especially for the soundtrack. So without further ado, if you like simplistic games and you like EDM music, like Monstercat or F-777, this game is for you.

I give Void Invaders an 8.0 out of 10.

All your bass are belong to us.

reviewText:
A gem among indie games.

You ever played one of those games where you feel like the devs got to make the game they wanted to make?

This is one of those games.  The premise is simple, it's basically Space Invaders on crack and it's absolutely awesome.

The game has three modes - level mode, where you fight fixed spawns (and also fixed weapon powerups) that never change but get progressively harder as you go up in levels.  You have a fixed box fight every 5 levels for a total of 30 levels.  This will be a good 2-3 hours of gameplay as the later stages get very challenging.

Endless Mode, which speaks for itself.  Enemies come at you nonstop in very random fashions.  All types of enemies with different flying patterns.  Later on during the mode it becomes absolute chaos as you try to manage staying alive before the next powerup.  Lots of fun!

Wave Mode, which is similar to Endless Mode but the enemies come at you in Galaxian-style waves" all clumped up together.  You can get powerups in this mode but only if you kill the entire line (or wave) of enemies.  Otherwise it's just staying alive as long as possible and going for the highest score.

The game has a variety of interesting powerups
recommended: triple and quadruple shot.  A double attack that doubles your current shots and can stack with the previous powerups I mentioned
voteText: a clone that replicates any shots you do (including powered up shots)
helpfulPercent: a "wave" shot similar to the semi-controllable laser in the Raiden series
votesTotal: which is essentially a wave powerup but fires in a sine/cosine wave without you needing to adjust it
column16: which makes your "ship" (which is a little space invader itself) fire in all directions.\n\nYou do not die in one hit in this game.  You have an HP bar and a very limited XP bar
column17: which you gain as you progress through Level Mode which allows you to do more damage and take more hits.  You'll understand in the later levels why an HP bar is needed rather than dying in one hit like most other hardcore shmups
column18: as the bullet patterns in this game are very random and can be tricky to dodge.\n\nThe game has Steam leaderboards for its Endless Mode and basic X360 controller support.  Options are limited
column19: but the game can practically run on a toaster because of how simple its graphics are.  There is no story whatsoever to speak of.  Just like the games of yesteryear
column20: your focus is to shoot down the flying alien bad guys.\n\nOh
column22: the music for this game is AWESOME.  Seems to be SoundTrekker style instruments in the form of EDM
column23: or electronic dance music.  If you're a fan of that genre you're going to absolutely LOVE the tracks that this game has.  Sound effects are old school style chips
column25: and blarps.  This game is definitely a love letter to the oldies out there.\n\nI picked this up on a sale for $0.49 and I feel like I ripped these guys off.  Even at full price (which is less than the price of a snack!) it's a lot of fun.  If you see this on sale during the Steam sale
column26: this is an absolute *no brainer*.  Get it.  You won't regret it."

reviewText:
Void Invaders is an retro-arcade like experience that plays similar to Space Invaders and Galaga. You face off against a horde of aliens with your‚Ä¶ um‚Ä¶ own alien? Yeah, you also control an alien ‚Äì I don‚Äôt know, maybe he turned rebel or something. Whatever.

Anyway, that‚Äôs pretty much all there is to it. There‚Äôs aliens, alien bosses, powerups, as well as a few modes to keep you occupied. It‚Äôs not too difficult to complete the game (in level mode at least); which is kind of refreshing actually, since most shoot ‚Äòem ups are utterly manic in the difficulty department. Definitely recommended for the casual gamer at least.

Overall, Void Invaders is more of a pleasant experience than it is a super hardcore shoot em up extravaganza. It won‚Äôt last too long, but there‚Äôs enough there to keep you entertained for a while.

Overall 70/100.

reviewText:
I'm still waiting for Galaga, Steam. Where are you?

You would figure that with all the arcade remakes ever to be made in this history of the world wide web, we can find a Galaga $15.00 rip-off with pretty colors remake on steam, but we don't live in that future just yet. We, in the modern era of the computerphone technology, live in arcade remakes of Space Invaders, not Galaga.

We have not progressed this far as a civilization to remake an amazing arcade game and continue to rely on the models of the old, conventional alternative (Space Invaders). This is like how we end institutional racism and deem racism socially unacceptable, but racism still persists in our culture in many different facets and never goes away. Space Invaders reboots are everywhere (persist in our culture) and come in many different aspects.

Void Invaders is not Galaga. It is 15% Galaga and 85% Space Invaders with pretty colors and/or seizures. While it is an 85% Space Invaders remake, Void Invaders has three different modes to the game: endless, wave (true arcade), and 'level', which is almost a storyline mode but with a level up system which doesn't really amount to anything. The level system also relies on power-ups to beat the level as the game gets tougher, but it doesn't detract from the experience (fun). Just because there's a clone-power up doesn't mean this game is Galaga. The ways to get powerups is also much different from Galaga because you don't die to get them, nor are their bonus rounds.

Where is my Galaga remake, Steam/Indie Game Developers? Don't you people remember what fun used to be??

tl;dr: It's cheap and great for all but the epileptics and colorblind folks. It's also not entirely space invaders but that doesn't mean it's Galaga. Where is Galaga, Steam?

reviewText:
Void Invaders is an extremely unique and delicious shmup! The music is intense and the visuals are a trip. I'm not really sure how else to describe it. It's just such an amazing game! Absolutely blew me away. The bosses feel soooo satisfying to defeat, then you're just put right back into the action of the next level!

Keep in mind that it's quite short, but there are multiple difficulties and an endless mode. There are achievements, but they're restricted to the game (not available on Steam itself).

Really solid game!

reviewText: There was a couple that met on some weird dating site. They liked each other that they went on a date.  They eventually get married and have a child. This couple is Galaga and Space Invaders, and their child is Void Invaders. While Void Invaders  looks like it's parents, it's got some weird attributes that can't really be found in the familiy tree, such as: a kickass modern electronic soundtrack, and A LOT OF FLASHING LIGHTS AND COLORS. Think of bringing a light machine gun to a rave where evil monsters that explode into light when killed are all gathered for a good time. I've only played a bit of Galaga. reviewText: An awesome game for anyone that enjoys the classics like Space Invaders and Galaga. Only problem for me is that it lacks controller support and that if you have epileptic seizures caused from bright lights and stuff like that, then I VERY highly recommend you stay from this game since thats almost like half its premise are the bright flashing lights.\n\nNow that the warning is out of the way, its a great game because it blends the classic gameplay of games like Space Invaders with the modern feel of shooting things to oblivian with plenty of powerups. This game even has MMO(ish) qualities where the farther you go, the more you level which increases things like damage, health, and fire rate are the big ones.

reviewText:
Space invaders with a twist
Whats new?
The tilt screen gimmick, which is sort of an  interesting concept
Sometimes the mechanic is used right, like being able to predict some of the enemy movement, as well as giving a unique look and feeling to this version of Space invaders
unfortunately for most of the game its disorienting idea.

Flaw
Its slow
trying to aim while the screen keeps wobbling left and right can be a long and arduous task
and its done quite intentionally as a way to add more time into an otherwise short game
The idea of putting Power ups on a timer is just, ridiculous. It becomes less about skill or pattern recognition and more about making the most out of the powers before they run out.
On later levels, running out of power ups equals starting up from the beginning all over again, no matter how much life there's left, there is no point even trying. As soon as its gone, enemies become authentic bullets sponges. Boss battles in particular take way too long to beat while maintaining the same attack pattern for most of the fight.

Void invaders is cheap and sort of visually appealing, but it lacks good gameplay

There has to be better ways to increase the difficulty, without making my weapons deal miserable damage

reviewText:
First-up, calling it Bullet Sponge Invaders" would be a lot more descriptive!

The game starts-off slow and stays that way for a while - weapon upgrades appear sometimes - enemies types are limited - patterns are uninteresting and it just keeps on repeating the boring stuff until the difficulty spikes and - well - I think it's too-little too-late by then.

FAR better shump games exist - many cost nothing - there's NO reason to buy this."
